elements.content: The effect of CH and CD quenching on the luminescence lifetime of Er3+, Nd3+, and Yb3+ in the Cs[Ln(HFA)4] system has been quantified, and we have shown that for Er3+ ions the quenching is dominated by the nearest neighbor CH oscillators, whereas for Nd3+ ions the roles of more distant CH oscillators and nearest neighbor CD oscillators are important.
elements.clean_text: The effect of CH and CD quenching on the luminescence lifetime of Er3+, Nd3+, and Yb3+ in the Cs[Ln(HFA)4] system has been quantified, and we have shown that for Er3+ ions the quenching is dominated by the nearest neighbor CH oscillators, whereas for Nd3+ ions the roles of more distant CH oscillators and nearest neighbor CD oscillators are important.

elements.content: Lanthanide-doped glasses have been widely studied, in part due to their use as optical gain media. Lanthanides have also been widely incorporated into organic hosts as the organic ligands can act as photosensitizers, resulting in much higher absorption cross sections, with broader absorption bands than for the free ions. However, ligands and coordinated solvent molecules usually contain C−H and O−H bonds that can cause vibrational quenching of the excited ions, and this limits any application of such complexes in infrared emitting devices. It is well-known that deuteration or fluorination of hydrogen-containing ligands, together with exclusion of coordinated water, can extend the lifetime of infrared luminescence from lanthanide complexes; however, there has been little quantitative work on the sensitivity of these ions to quenching through these processes. Nd(III) has been a subject of particular study although even here there is little quantitative data. Recent work by Quochi et al. has attempted to address this point for Er3+ ions through a theoretical model based on a continuous medium approximation.
elements.clean_text:
1. Introduction

Lanthanide-doped glasses have been widely studied, in part due to their use as optical gain media. Lanthanides have also been widely incorporated into organic hosts as the organic ligands can act as photosensitizers, resulting in much higher absorption cross sections, with broader absorption bands than for the free ions. However, ligands and coordinated solvent molecules usually contain C-H and O-H bonds that can cause vibrational quenching of the excited ions, and this limits any application of such complexes in infrared emitting devices. It is well-known that deuteration or fluorination of hydrogen-containing ligands, together with exclusion of coordinated water, can extend the lifetime of infrared luminescence from lanthanide complexes; however, there has been little quantitative work on the sensitivity of these ions to quenching through these processes. Nd(III) has been a subject of particular study although even here there is little quantitative data. Recent work by Quochi et al. has attempted to address this point for Er3+ ions through a theoretical model based on a continuous medium approximation.

elements.content: In order to quantitatively study the effect of C−H bonds on the radiative lifetime of Er3+, Nd3+, and Yb3+ ions and to determine the spatial distance over which de-excitation can occur, we have investigated the role of deuteration on the luminescence lifetimes of the tetrakis complexes Cs[Ln(HFA)4] (H−HFA = 1,1,1,5,5,5-hexafluoro-2,4-pentanedione; Ln = Er, Nd, Yb) to study the effect of removing CH oscillators. This system results in each ion residing in a symmetrical environment with only four equivalent CH bonds in the nearest neighbor positions. We have shown that for Er3+ ions the luminescence lifetime is dominated by the CH oscillators in the nearest neighbor positions, whereas for Nd3+ ions the more distant CH and nearest neighbor CD oscillators play an important role. For Yb3+ it is suggested that, due to the large energy gap for the ion, a cooperative energy transfer may be operating in addition to nonradiative energy transfer between ions.
elements.clean_text: In order to quantitatively study the effect of C-H bonds on the radiative lifetime of Er3+, Nd3+, and Yb3+ ions and to determine the spatial distance over which de-excitation can occur, we have investigated the role of deuteration on the luminescence lifetimes of the tetrakis complexes Cs[Ln(HFA)4] (H-HFA = 1,1,1,5,5,5-hexafluoro-2,4-pentanedione; Ln = Er, Nd, Yb) to study the effect of removing CH oscillators. This system results in each ion residing in a symmetrical environment with only four equivalent CH bonds in the nearest neighbor positions. We have shown that for Er3+ ions the luminescence lifetime is dominated by the CH oscillators in the nearest neighbor positions, whereas for Nd3+ ions the more distant CH and nearest neighbor CD oscillators play an important role. For Yb3+ it is suggested that, due to the large energy gap for the ion, a cooperative energy transfer may be operating in addition to nonradiative energy transfer between ions.

elements.content: Cs[Er(HFA) 4 ] was prepared by mixing aqueous Cs+ HFA- with the calculated amount of aqueous erbium(III) chloride; the pink precipitate was recrystallized from aqueous methanol to give pink needles, mp 276−278 °C; single-crystal X-ray diffraction (Figure ) showed that this material was isomorphous with Cs[Eu(HFA)4]. Elemental analysis found C, 20.9; H, 0.3; C20H4CsErF24O8 requires C, 21.3; H, 0.4; m/z (ES−) found 993.8828; C20H4 166ErF24O8 (M−Cs+) requires 993.8831; νmax/cm-1 (KBr) 3161 (C−H) and 1653 (CO). Crystal data for Cs[Er(HFA)4]:  C20H4CsErF24O8, M = 1128.40, orthorhombic, a = 8.534(3), b = 21.189(5), c = 17.251(8) Å, α = 90.00°, β = 90.00°, γ =90.00°, V = 3119(2) Å3, space group Pbcn, Z = 4, D c = 2.403 Mg/m3, λ = 0.71073 Å, μ = 4.027 mm-1, reflections measured 3057, reflections unique 2890 with R int = 0.0102, T = 160(2) K, final R indices [I > 2σ(I)] R 1 = 0.0430, wR 2 = 0.1044 and for all data R 1 = 0.1010, wR 2 = 0.1288. CCDC 292801.
elements.clean_text:
2. Experimental Methods

 Cs[Er(HFA)  4  ] was prepared by mixing aqueous Cs+ HFA- with the calculated amount of aqueous erbium(III) chloride; the pink precipitate was recrystallized from aqueous methanol to give pink needles, mp 276-278 °C; single-crystal X-ray diffraction (Figure ) showed that this material was isomorphous with Cs[Eu(HFA)4]. Elemental analysis found C, 20.9; H, 0.3; C20H4CsErF24O8 requires C, 21.3; H, 0.4; m/z (ES-) found 993.8828; C20H4 166ErF24O8 (M-Cs+) requires 993.8831; νmax/cm-1 (KBr) 3161 (C-H) and 1653 (CO). Crystal data for Cs[Er(HFA)4]: C20H4CsErF24O8, M = 1128.40, orthorhombic, a = 8.534(3), b = 21.189(5), c = 17.251(8) Å, α = 90.00°, β = 90.00°, γ =90.00°, V = 3119(2) Å3, space group Pbcn, Z = 4, D c = 2.403 Mg/m3, λ = 0.71073 Å, μ = 4.027 mm-1, reflections measured 3057, reflections unique 2890 with R int = 0.0102, T = 160(2) K, final R indices [I > 2σ(I)] R 1 = 0.0430, wR 2 = 0.1044 and for all data R 1 = 0.1010, wR 2 = 0.1288. CCDC 292801.

elements.content: Molecular structure of Cs[Er(HFA)4].

elements.content: Cs[Er(HFA) 4 ]- d 4 was prepared by using D2O and CH3OD as solvents in the above procedure; ErCl3·6H2O was evaporated from D2O several times before starting the experiment, and the H−HFA was subjected to a preliminary H/D exchange by stirring with Et2O and D2O for 24 h, followed by distillation of the Et2O extract from P2O5 according to the method of Ogoshi and Nakamoto. Cs[Er(HFA)4]-d 4 had a mp of 270−272 °C; m/z (ES−) found 997.9076; C20D4 166ErF24O8 (M−Cs+) requires 997.9082; m/z (MALDI) found 994 (1.0%), 995 (1.5), 996 (5.9), 997 (13.7), 998 (100), 999 (92.5), 1000 (94.9), 1001 (26.5), 1002 (47.5), 1003 (9.6), 1004 (1.5); C20D4ErF24O8 with 98% deuteration requires 994 (0.4), 995 (0.4), 996 (4.7), 997 (8.7), 998 (100), 999 (91.2), 1000 (93.0), 1001 (22.7), 1002 (45.1), 1003 (9.4), 1004 (1.6); νmax/cm-1 (KBr) 1653 (CO).

elements.content:
Nd and Yb complexes were prepared similarly to the Er analogues.

Cs[Nd(HFA) 4 ]:  pale purple solid, mp 191−192 °C (lit. 191−192 °C) m/z (ES−) found 969.8607; C20H4F24 142NdO8 (M−Cs+) requires 969.8606; νmax/cm-1 (KBr) 3157 (C−H), 1647 (CO).

Cs[Nd(HFA) 4 ]- d 4 :  mp 196−200 °C, m/z (ES−) found 973.8845; C20D4F24 142NdO8 (M−Cs+) requires 973.8857; m/z (MALDI) found 972 (0.9%), 973 (10.8), 974 (100), 975 (70.4), 976 (95.7), 977 (53.7), 978 (71.0), 979 (16.1), 980 (23.9), 981 (6.2), 982 (22.2), 983 (0.6), 984 (0.1); C20D4F24NdO8 with 98% deuteration requires 972 (0.2), 973 (7.8), 974 (100), 975 (71.0), 976 (99.8), 977 (54.8), 978 (70.5), 979 (16.4), 980 (22.6), 981 (6.1), 982 (20.6), 983 (4.2), 984 (0.8); νmax/cm-1 (KBr) 1647 (CO).

Cs[Yb(HFA) 4 ]:  white solid, mp ca. 280 °C (decomp), m/z (ES−) found 1001.8937; C20H4F24O8 174Yb (M−Cs+) requires 1001.8917; νmax/cm-1 (KBr) 3151 (C−H), 1654 (CO).

Cs[Yb(HFA) 4 ]- d 4 :  mp ca. 280 °C (decomp), m/z (ES−) found 1005.9152; C20D4F24O8 174Yb (M−Cs+) requires 1005.9157; m/z (MALDI) found 1000 (3.7%), 1001 (5.5), 1002 (15.8), 1003 (46.3), 1004 (75.1), 1005 (64.8), 1006 (100), 1007 (17.0), 1008 (33.2), 1009 (5.9); C20D4F24O8Yb with 96% deuteration requires 1000 (0.4), 1001 (0.5), 1002 (10.8), 1003 (44.9), 1004 (72.0), 1005 (64.4), 1006 (100), 1007 (24.0), 1008 (38.7), 1009 (8.0), 1010 (1.3); νmax/cm-1 (KBr) 1647 (CO).

Partially deuterated Cs[Ln(HFA)4] samples were prepared by dissolving Cs[Ln(HFA)4] (0.03 mmol) in 0.3 mL of a CH3OH/CH3OD mixture of the desired composition and adding H−HFA (0.02 mmol). The solutions were kept at room temperature for 24 h, then rotary evaporated. The residues was triturated with Et2O, then dried over P2O5 in a vacuum desiccator. The extent of deuteration in each sample was determined by analysis of the MALDI mass spectrometry data (Bruker Daltonics Autoflex).
elements.clean_text: Partially deuterated Cs[Ln(HFA)4] samples were prepared by dissolving Cs[Ln(HFA)4] (0.03 mmol) in 0.3 mL of a CH3OH/CH3OD mixture of the desired composition and adding H-HFA (0.02 mmol). The solutions were kept at room temperature for 24 h, then rotary evaporated. The residues was triturated with Et2O, then dried over P2O5 in a vacuum desiccator. The extent of deuteration in each sample was determined by analysis of the MALDI mass spectrometry data (Bruker Daltonics Autoflex).

elements.content: Photoluminescence from the complexes was excited using ∼7 ns pulses from a Continuum Panther optical parametric oscillator (OPO) pumped with a Surelite I laser. For erbium, an excitation wavelength of 520 nm was chosen to provide direct excitation into the 4S3/2 level of the Er3+ ion which rapidly decays to the 4I13/2 level with a measured decay time of the order of 25 ns. For neodymium and ytterbium excitation, wavelengths of 420 and 460 nm were used, respectively. The luminescence was dispersed in a Triax 550 spectrometer and detected using a Hamamastu R5509-72 infrared photomultiplier tube.
elements.clean_text: Photoluminescence from the complexes was excited using ~7 ns pulses from a Continuum Panther optical parametric oscillator (OPO) pumped with a Surelite I laser. For erbium, an excitation wavelength of 520 nm was chosen to provide direct excitation into the 4S3/2 level of the Er3+ ion which rapidly decays to the 4I13/2 level with a measured decay time of the order of 25 ns. For neodymium and ytterbium excitation, wavelengths of 420 and 460 nm were used, respectively. The luminescence was dispersed in a Triax 550 spectrometer and detected using a Hamamastu R5509-72 infrared photomultiplier tube.

elements.content: Lifetime data were recorded at the peak of the photoluminescence spectra at a temperature of 300 K. For erbium this corresponded to the 4I13/2 → 4I15/2 transition (1542 nm) and for ytterbium the 2F5/2 → 2F7/2 transition (1032 nm). For neodymium, data were recorded for the 4F3/2 → 4I9/2 (920 nm), 4F3/2 → 4I11/2 (1045 nm), and 4F3/2 → 4I13/2 (1340 nm) transitions; only the 4F3/2 → 4I9/2 (1045 nm) transition is presented because all the lifetimes were identical. Lifetime data are fitted with either a one-, two-, or three-exponential decay model using a Marquardt−Levenberg algorithm to find the best fit.
elements.clean_text: Lifetime data were recorded at the peak of the photoluminescence spectra at a temperature of 300 K. For erbium this corresponded to the 4I13/2 → 4I15/2 transition (1542 nm) and for ytterbium the 2F5/2 → 2F7/2 transition (1032 nm). For neodymium, data were recorded for the 4F3/2 → 4I9/2 (920 nm), 4F3/2 → 4I11/2 (1045 nm), and 4F3/2 → 4I13/2 (1340 nm) transitions; only the 4F3/2 → 4I9/2 (1045 nm) transition is presented because all the lifetimes were identical. Lifetime data are fitted with either a one-, two-, or three-exponential decay model using a Marquardt-Levenberg algorithm to find the best fit.

elements.content: It has been reported that Nd(HFA)3(H2O)2 underwent deuteration of the HFA ligand when it was kept in CD3OD solution for 6 h. We were surprised to find that the H/D isotopic exchange of Cs[Er(HFA)4] in CH3OD solution was extremely slow (<20% complete after 3 days at 25 °C), presumably because ligand that is bound in the anionic lanthanide complex cannot easily lose H+. The addition of a small quantity of free H−HFA ligand greatly accelerated the deuteration of the complex, enabling >90% exchange to be achieved in 24 h at 25 °C.
elements.clean_text:
3. Results and Discussion

It has been reported that Nd(HFA)3(H2O)2 underwent deuteration of the HFA ligand when it was kept in CD3OD solution for 6 h. We were surprised to find that the H/D isotopic exchange of Cs[Er(HFA)4] in CH3OD solution was extremely slow (<20% complete after 3 days at 25 °C), presumably because ligand that is bound in the anionic lanthanide complex cannot easily lose H+. The addition of a small quantity of free H-HFA ligand greatly accelerated the deuteration of the complex, enabling >90% exchange to be achieved in 24 h at 25 °C.

elements.content: For Cs[Er(HFA)4] nine samples were prepared with deuteration levels of 0%, 30%, 47%, 58%, 87%, 90%, 94%, and 98%. All deuteration levels were calculated from the mass spectra of the [Er(HFA)4]- anion using laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry and have an error of ± 2%. The results for the lifetime fits to the luminescence of these samples are given in Table . Only the undeuterated sample data could be fitted with a single-exponential fit, which is indicative of all the ions being in identical environments. For the 98% deuterated sample there was a small component (∼4%) to the lifetime decay which had a very long lifetime, ∼106 μs. In an earlier paper we proposed that this is due to a small number of Er3+ ions being in environments where there are no CH oscillators within ∼20 Å of the ion. However, for the intermediate levels of deuteration it can be seen that only the 30% deuteration sample gave three lifetime components, and for all the other samples the data could be adequately fitted using a dual-exponential model. These results are in contradiction to the theoretical result proposed by Quochi et al. who estimated the rate constant for quenching of erbium ions in an organic matrix by assuming that the nonradiative decay could be modeled using a continuous medium approximation with a minimum distance, R min, between the ions and the acceptors. This gave a simple expression for the rate constant, k nr,
elements.clean_text: For Cs[Er(HFA)4] nine samples were prepared with deuteration levels of 0%, 30%, 47%, 58%, 87%, 90%, 94%, and 98%. All deuteration levels were calculated from the mass spectra of the [Er(HFA)4]- anion using laser desorption/ionization mass spectrometry and have an error of ± 2%. The results for the lifetime fits to the luminescence of these samples are given in Table . Only the undeuterated sample data could be fitted with a single-exponential fit, which is indicative of all the ions being in identical environments. For the 98% deuterated sample there was a small component (~4%) to the lifetime decay which had a very long lifetime, ~106 μs. In an earlier paper we proposed that this is due to a small number of Er3+ ions being in environments where there are no CH oscillators within ~20 Å of the ion. However, for the intermediate levels of deuteration it can be seen that only the 30% deuteration sample gave three lifetime components, and for all the other samples the data could be adequately fitted using a dual-exponential model. These results are in contradiction to the theoretical result proposed by Quochi et al. who estimated the rate constant for quenching of erbium ions in an organic matrix by assuming that the nonradiative decay could be modeled using a continuous medium approximation with a minimum distance, R min, between the ions and the acceptors. This gave a simple expression for the rate constant, k nr,

elements.content:
Measured Lifetimes of the 1542 nm Emission from the Er3+ 4I13/2 → 4I15/2 Transition in Deuterated Cs[Er(HFA)4] a

deuteration level (%) τ1 (μs) τ2 (μs) τ3 (μs) 0 1.8 (100) 30 1.8 (37) 3.0 (55)  10 (8) 47 2.4 (46) 5.5 (54) 58 2.5 (31) 6.0 (68) 81 3.3 (17) 8.4 (83) 87 3.7 (11) 9.5 (89) 90 3.5 (10) 10 (90) 94 3.6 (6) 10.6 (94) 98 11 (96) ∼106 (4)

a  The figures in parentheses are the percentage contribution from each component.

For our deuterated samples R min effectively does not change as even at 70% deuteration >75% of the lanthanide ions still have at least one CH bond within their four directly coordinated ligands, and for our 30% deuterated sample >99% of the complexes contain at least one hydrogen atom. The Quochi model naturally gives an “average” deactivation rate constant and hence would predict a single lifetime decay that would be proportional to the strength of the vibrational absorption averaged over the erbium spectral emission window, 〈αA〉Er. This term would be directly proportional to the average concentration of CH oscillators in the material. Hence, for as long as R min remains unchanged the lifetime will be single exponential and linearly proportional to the deuteration level.
elements.clean_text: For our deuterated samples R min effectively does not change as even at 70% deuteration >75% of the lanthanide ions still have at least one CH bond within their four directly coordinated ligands, and for our 30% deuterated sample >99% of the  complexes contain at least one hydrogen atom. The Quochi model naturally gives an "average" deactivation rate constant and hence would predict a single lifetime decay that would be proportional to the strength of the vibrational absorption averaged over the erbium spectral emission window, 〈αA〉Er. This term would be directly proportional to the average concentration of CH oscillators in the material. Hence, for as long as R min remains unchanged the lifetime will be single exponential and linearly proportional to the deuteration level.

elements.content: For the undeuterated sample it is clear that all Er3+ ions are in equivalent positions. These ions each have four CH oscillators in nearest neighbor positions within the Er(HFA)4 - anion, at 4.7 Å from XRD data, and then some distribution of CH oscillators corresponding to neighboring anions at distances greater than 6.962 Å, the next nearest neighbor position. This sample has a single-exponential decay with a lifetime of 1.8 μs. If we assume that it is only the four CH oscillators on the Er(HFA)4 - anion which are contributing to this lifetime, this gives a rate constant for each CH oscillator of ∼140 000 s-1. Using this rate constant for a single CH oscillator at 4.7 Å we can calculate the predicted lifetimes for anions with between one and three hydrogen atoms present. This gives a predicted lifetime of 2.4 μs for [Er(HFA)4-d 1]-, 3.6 μs for [Er(HFA)4-d 2]-, and 7.2 μs for [Er(HFA)4-d 3]-. From Table it can be seen that for each of the partially deuterated samples the fastest lifetime observed corresponds to the predicted lifetime for either the d 0 (30%), d 1 (47% and 58%), or d 2 (81%, 87%, 90%, and 94%) species. It should be noted that for each sample up to 81% deuteration the lowest lifetime that could be measured corresponded to the site with the largest number of hydrogen atoms present, providing that the concentration was greater than ∼10%. For deuteration levels >81% we were able to measure the 3.6 μs component, corresponding to the [Er(HFA)4-d 2]- anion, even when it was present at levels down to 3%. This suggests that for Er3+ ions, providing there are at least two CH oscillators in the nearest neighbor positions, it is the contribution of these nearest neighbor CH oscillators which dominates the quenching. Once there is only one CH oscillator in this nearest neighbor position the contribution of the more distant oscillators becomes much more significant. For these samples, except in the case of the 30% deuterated sample, we were always able to accurately model the lifetime data using a double-exponential decay. This does not mean that there were only two lifetimes present in these samples but rather that, apart from the fast component, there is not a unique solution to the deconvolution of the various lifetime components and our approach gives the “best-fit” with the minimum number of fitting parameters. We did try fitting all the samples with up to five exponential decay processes forcing the lifetimes for each process to the values calculated for each local environment (i.e., d 0−d 3) and using the measured value of 11 μs for [Er(HFA)4-d 4]-. With the use of this approach, the prefactors were the only free fitting parameter. Excellent fits were obtained for each sample, and the percentage contribution calculated from the fits were in reasonable agreement with those predicted (Table ).

These ions each have four CH oscillators in nearest neighbor positions within the Er(HFA)4 - anion, at 4.7 Å from XRD data, and then some distribution of CH oscillators corresponding to neighboring anions at distances greater than 6.962 Å, the next nearest neighbor position. This sample has a single-exponential decay with a lifetime of 1.8 μs. If we assume that it is only the four CH oscillators on the Er(HFA)4 - anion which are contributing to this lifetime, this gives a rate constant for each CH oscillator of ~140000 s-1. Using this rate constant for a single CH oscillator at 4.7 Å we can calculate the predicted lifetimes for anions with between one and three hydrogen atoms present. This gives a predicted lifetime of 2.4 μs for [Er(HFA)4-d 1]-, 3.6 μs for [Er(HFA)4-d 2]-, and 7.2 μs for [Er(HFA)4-d 3]-. From Table  it can be seen that for each of the partially deuterated samples the fastest lifetime observed corresponds to the predicted lifetime for either the d 0 (30%), d 1 (47% and 58%), or d 2 (81%, 87%, 90%, and 94%) species. It should be noted that for each sample up to 81% deuteration the lowest lifetime that could be measured corresponded to the site with the largest number of hydrogen atoms present, providing that the concentration was greater than ~10%. For deuteration levels >81% we were able to measure the 3.6 μs component, corresponding to the [Er(HFA)4-d 2]- anion, even when it was present at levels down to 3%. This suggests that for Er3+ ions, providing there are at least two CH oscillators in the nearest neighbor positions, it is the contribution of these nearest neighbor CH oscillators which dominates the quenching. Once there is only one CH oscillator in this nearest neighbor position the contribution of the more distant oscillators becomes much more significant. For these samples, except in the case of the 30% deuterated sample, we were always able to accurately model the lifetime data using a double-exponential decay. This does not mean that there were only two lifetimes present in these samples but rather that, apart from the fast component, there is not a unique solution to the deconvolution of the various lifetime components and our approach gives the "best-fit" with the minimum number of fitting parameters. We did try fitting all the samples with up to five exponential decay processes forcing the lifetimes for each process to the values calculated for each local environment (i.e., d 0-d 3) and using the measured value of 11 μs for [Er(HFA)4-d 4]-. With the use of this approach, the prefactors were the only free fitting parameter. Excellent fits were obtained for each sample, and the percentage contribution calculated from the fits were in reasonable agreement with those predicted (Table ).

30% 47% 58% 81% 87% 90% 94% deuteration level C M C M C M C M C M C M C M d0 24 34 9 9 3 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 0 d1 41 32 29 16 18 20 3 0 1 0 0 0 0 0 d2 26 24 37 48 36 35 15 18 8 7 6 7 3 4 d3 8 10 21 27 32 45 41 48 34 37 31 24 22 12 d4 1 0 4 0 11 0 41 34 57 56 63 69 75 84

For the Cs[Nd(HFA)4], six samples were prepared with deuteration levels of 0%, 49%, 59%, 60%, 85%, and 98%. For all of these samples a dual-exponential fit was needed to fit the data and the results are given in Table . For all the samples it can be seen that the minor lifetime component is very fast (i.e., <1 μs). From our earlier work on [Er(HFA)3(H2O)2]11 we have been able to attribute these submicrosecond lifetimes to water in the ion coordination sphere. It is known that the Nd3+ ion can have a coordination number of eight or nine, so that both Cs[Nd(HFA)4] and Cs[Nd(HFA)4(H2O)] can be formed, and the water is not entirely removed from the latter complex even by vacuum sublimation. The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the Cs[Nd(HFA)4] was consistent with the anhydrous structure, but we suspected that the short lifetime component is due to a small amount of coordinated water. We therefore deliberately hydrated the material by leaving it for several days in a sealed container with an open beaker of water, whereupon the sample gained the amount of mass expected for the addition of one equivalent of water. For both the Cs[Nd(HFA)4] and Cs[Nd(HFA-d)4] samples this procedure produced an almost pure single lifetime process of 0.18 μs. Subsequent sublimation of this material did not significantly increase the lifetime, so it appears that once water has been introduced into the coordination sphere it is difficult to remove, which is in keeping with the observations of Danford et al. These results support the view that the fast lifetime components seen in our partially deuterated samples are due to the presence of some hydrated ions. For anhydrous material we can therefore conclude that the lifetime for Nd3+ in a [Nd(HFA)4]- anion is 1.65 μs. Using the same argument as for erbium this would predict lifetimes for the partially deuterated anions of 2.2 μs for [Nd(HFA)4-d 1], 3.3 μs for [Nd(HFA)4-d 2], and 6.6 μs for [Nd(HFA)4-d 3]. Given that this calculated value for [Nd(HFA)4-d 3] is considerably greater than the measured value for the 98% deuterated sample (4.2 μs), this shows that for Nd3+ ions either the more distant CH oscillators or nearest neighbor CD oscillators play a significant role on the ion quenching. The importance of CD oscillators on the quenching can be seen from Figure , where we schematically show the relative energies of the quenching transition for each of the ions along with the energy of the CH and CD oscillators and their harmonics. For erbium it appears that the role of CD oscillators is less important as it is the third harmonic that would be needed to quench the ion. In Figure we have plotted the rate constant obtained from the major lifetime components in the neodymium data against the percentage deuteration. It can be seen that the data fit a straight line, as would be expected from the continuous medium approximation model used by Quochi et al. This increased sensitivity to the effect of more distant CH oscillators or the sensitivity to CD oscillators in the nearest neighbor positions is probably the cause of this linear dependence.
elements.clean_text: For the Cs[Nd(HFA)4], six samples were prepared with deuteration levels of 0%, 49%, 59%, 60%, 85%, and 98%. For all of these samples a dual-exponential fit was needed to fit the data and the results are given in Table . For all the samples it can be seen that the minor lifetime component is very fast (i.e., <1 μs). From our earlier work on [Er(HFA)3(H2O)2]11 we have been able to attribute these submicrosecond lifetimes to water in the ion coordination sphere. It is known that the Nd3+ ion can have a coordination number of eight or nine, so that both Cs[Nd(HFA)4] and Cs[Nd(HFA)4(H2O)] can be formed, and the water is not entirely removed from the latter complex even by vacuum sublimation. The powder X-ray diffraction pattern of the Cs[Nd(HFA)4] was consistent with the anhydrous structure, but we suspected that the short lifetime component is due to a small amount of coordinated water. We therefore deliberately hydrated the material by leaving it for several days in a sealed container with an open beaker of water, whereupon the sample gained the amount of mass expected for the addition of one equivalent of water. For both the Cs[Nd(HFA)4] and Cs[Nd(HFA-d)4] samples this procedure produced an almost pure single lifetime process of 0.18 μs. Subsequent sublimation of this material did not significantly increase the lifetime, so it appears that once water has been introduced into the coordination sphere it is difficult to remove, which is in keeping with the observations of Danford et al. These results support the view that the fast lifetime components seen in our partially deuterated samples are due to the presence of some hydrated ions. For anhydrous material we can therefore conclude that the lifetime for Nd3+ in a [Nd(HFA)4]- anion is 1.65 μs. Using the same argument as for erbium this would predict lifetimes for the partially deuterated anions of 2.2 μs for [Nd(HFA)4-d 1], 3.3 μs for [Nd(HFA)4-d 2], and 6.6 μs for [Nd(HFA)4-d 3]. Given that this calculated value for [Nd(HFA)4-d 3] is considerably greater than the measured value for the 98% deuterated sample (4.2 μs), this shows that for Nd3+ ions either the more distant CH oscillators or nearest neighbor CD oscillators play a significant role on the ion quenching. The importance of CD oscillators on the quenching can be seen from Figure , where we schematically show the relative energies of the quenching transition for each of the ions along with the energy of the CH and CD oscillators and their harmonics. For erbium it appears that the role of CD oscillators is less important as it is the third harmonic that would be needed to quench the ion. In Figure  we have plotted the rate constant obtained from the major lifetime components in the neodymium data against the percentage deuteration. It can be seen that the data fit a straight line, as would be expected from the continuous medium approximation model used by Quochi et al. This increased sensitivity to the effect of more distant CH oscillators or the sensitivity to  CD oscillators in the nearest neighbor positions is probably the cause of this linear dependence.

elements.content:
Measured Lifetimes of the 1340 nm Emission from the Nd3+ 4I13/2 → 4I15/2 Transition in Deuterated Cs[Nd(HFA)4] a

deuteration level (%) τ1 (μs) τ2 (μs) 0 0.4 (8) 1.65 (92) 49 0.3 (1) 2.4 (99)  59 0.3 (3) 2.6 (97) 60 0.5 (3) 2.7 (97) 85 0.6 (2) 3.6 (98) 98 0.7 (4) 4.2 (96)

a  The figures in parentheses are the percentage contribution from each component.

For Cs[Yb(HFA)4], six samples were prepared with deuteration levels of 0%, 32%, 53%, 66%, 86%, and 96%. For each sample the luminescence lifetime could be fitted with a single-exponential decay. The lifetimes for the different samples were 21.6 μs (0%), 33.7 μs (32%), 47.4 μs (53%), 65.5 μs (66%), 130.4 μs (86%), and 289 μs (96%). The fact that each of these samples showed a single-exponential decay process suggests that they are not dominated by the number of CH oscillators in the nearest neighbor sites in the way that erbium is. However, the strong dependence of the recombination lifetime on the level of deuteration does show that CH oscillators are definitely the dominant quenching mechanism. It is not clear why Yb3+ shows only single-exponential decay for all samples. However, given that the energy gap for the transition (∼9700 cm-1) in Yb3+ is much bigger than for either of the other ions and three times the CH oscillator energy it is possible that the dominant Yb3+ de-excitation may be cooperative energy transfer to more than one CH oscillator. Such a process would be inefficient and be much more sensitive to the removal of a single hydrogen atom from the anion. It is also possible that with the increased lifetime for Yb3+ with increasing deuteration that Yb−Yb energy migration may occur before a site with a suitable environment for efficient quenching is encountered.
elements.clean_text: For Cs[Yb(HFA)4], six samples were prepared with deuteration levels of 0%, 32%, 53%, 66%, 86%, and 96%. For each sample the luminescence lifetime could be fitted with a single-exponential decay. The lifetimes for the different samples were 21.6 μs (0%), 33.7 μs (32%), 47.4 μs (53%), 65.5 μs (66%), 130.4 μs (86%), and 289 μs (96%). The fact that each of these samples showed a single-exponential decay process suggests that they are not dominated by the number of CH oscillators in the nearest neighbor sites in the way that erbium is. However, the strong dependence of the recombination lifetime on the level of deuteration does show that CH oscillators are definitely the dominant quenching mechanism. It is not clear why Yb3+ shows only single-exponential decay for all samples. However, given that the energy gap for the transition (~9700 cm-1) in Yb3+ is much bigger than for either of the other ions and three times the CH oscillator energy it is possible that the dominant Yb3+ de-excitation may be cooperative energy transfer to more than one CH oscillator. Such a process would be inefficient and be much more sensitive to the removal of a single hydrogen atom from the anion. It is also possible that with the increased lifetime for Yb3+ with increasing deuteration that Yb-Yb energy migration may occur before a site with a suitable environment for efficient quenching is encountered.

elements.content: We have performed a detailed study of the role of CH and CD oscillators on the quenching of Er3+, Nd3+, and Yb3+ ions in the Cs[Ln(HFA)4] system. The results show that for Er3+ ions the rapid luminescence quenching is strongly dependent on the immediate local environment with only a secondary effect due to more distant CH bonds. This result is contrary to the theoretical prediction of Quochi et al. obtained from their continuous medium approximation. For Nd3+ and Yb3+ ions single-exponential decay was observed for anhydrous ions at all deuteration levels and the rate constant for quenching was found to vary linearly with deuteration level.
elements.clean_text:
4. Conclusions

We have performed a detailed study of the role of CH and CD oscillators on the quenching of Er3+, Nd3+, and Yb3+ ions in the Cs[Ln(HFA)4] system. The results show that for Er3+ ions the rapid luminescence quenching is strongly dependent on the immediate local environment with only a secondary effect due to more distant CH bonds. This result is contrary to the theoretical prediction of Quochi et al. obtained from their continuous medium approximation. For Nd3+ and Yb3+ ions single-exponential decay was observed for anhydrous ions at all deuteration levels and the rate constant for quenching was found to vary linearly with deuteration level.

cln_elements.content:
Cs[Er(HFA) 4 ] was prepared by mixing aqueous Cs+ HFA- with the calculated amount of aqueous erbium(III) chloride; the pink precipitate was recrystallized from aqueous methanol to give pink needles, mp 276−278 °C; single-crystal X-ray diffraction (Figure ) showed that this material was isomorphous with Cs[Eu(HFA)4]. Elemental analysis found C, 20.9; H, 0.3; C20H4CsErF24O8 requires C, 21.3; H, 0.4; m/z (ES−) found 993.8828; C20H4 166ErF24O8 (M−Cs+) requires 993.8831; νmax/cm-1 (KBr) 3161 (C−H) and 1653 (CO). Crystal data for Cs[Er(HFA)4]:  C20H4CsErF24O8, M = 1128.40, orthorhombic, a = 8.534(3), b = 21.189(5), c = 17.251(8) Å, α = 90.00°, β = 90.00°, γ =90.00°, V = 3119(2) Å3, space group Pbcn, Z = 4, D c = 2.403 Mg/m3, λ = 0.71073 Å, μ = 4.027 mm-1, reflections measured 3057, reflections unique 2890 with R int = 0.0102, T = 160(2) K, final R indices [I > 2σ(I)] R 1 = 0.0430, wR 2 = 0.1044 and for all data R 1 = 0.1010, wR 2 = 0.1288. CCDC 292801.

Cs[Yb(HFA) 4 ]:  white solid, mp ca. 280 °C (decomp), m/z (ES−) found 1001.8937; C20H4F24O8 174Yb (M−Cs+) requires 1001.8917; νmax/cm-1 (KBr) 3151 (C−H), 1654 (CO).

Cs[Yb(HFA) 4 ]- d 4 :  mp ca. 280 °C (decomp), m/z (ES−) found 1005.9152; C20D4F24O8 174Yb (M−Cs+) requires 1005.9157; m/z (MALDI) found 1000 (3.7%), 1001 (5.5), 1002 (15.8), 1003 (46.3), 1004 (75.1), 1005 (64.8), 1006 (100), 1007 (17.0), 1008 (33.2), 1009 (5.9); C20D4F24O8Yb with 96% deuteration requires 1000 (0.4), 1001 (0.5), 1002 (10.8), 1003 (44.9), 1004 (72.0), 1005 (64.4), 1006 (100), 1007 (24.0), 1008 (38.7), 1009 (8.0), 1010 (1.3); νmax/cm-1 (KBr) 1647 (CO).
